reviewText: I LIKE IT.

Not a believable plot line at all, the writer should have taken the extra 5 minutes and at least developed a logical introduction. ...cliche at best

Interesting tale of degradation behind bars, if somewhat improbable, but with a satisfying conclusion.

Another in a long genre of prison movies which feature the star of the film as being moral upon all reproach. Not wrongfully convicted as he accepted a plea agreement offer in order to secure a short sentence. One would like to think this person would have been acquitted after a trial as he purely acted in self-defense. And, yes, wrongful convictions are too common here in the States also.

This is a clich fest with vanilla characters and wooden performances. There are so many of these wrong guy in prison movies. He goes to jail for a clear self defense situation so that would never happen in the states. Once he arrives in his Aussie cell more tropes and situations we've seen a million times before. If you want to watch better prison movie watch the Tom Selleck 1989 movie called A Wrong Man. Or for the mother of all great dude in prison movies check out the other 1989 classic called Lock Up with Sylvester Stallone.
Great FIGHTING Australian movie. So good! If you like prison films you'll love this. Corruption and all....

"Convict" is the Australian version of a man wrongfully accused gone to prison and harassed, but fights back film. Ray (George Basha -also wrote/directed)  is convicted of manslaughter of a rich kid when it was clearly self defense. As always they can never get a good premise to put an innocent person in jail. He is also a war hero and uses his skills to survive, i.e. beat up guys 10 times his size...but he can never handle two of them. The warden is payed to make his life difficult.

This kind of film hasn't been done in at least a month, so it was so refreshing ;) Seriously, it held my interest even though it  lacked memorable tough guy sound bites and Pamela Grier. Worth a view if you are into the tough prison guy thing.

F-bomb. Male butt nudity. No sex.

Absolute, worthless garbage.  Save yourself the headache and watch... well... just about any other movie ever made.  As if this movie wasn't ridiculous enough, they have to include the awkwardly unnecessary man on man rape scene that seems to be the hallmark of every poorly conceived prison movie.  If anyone out there thinks that their IQ is too high and wants to knock it down a couple dozen points, I'd recommend you try and sit through the first thirty minutes of this movie.  Good luck to ya!

I'll give it a solid three stars on content, but give me a break please. You couldn't get the military to come down and put together a realistic uniform!!?? The beret looks like a pizza hat, the uniform is too big, you don't mix ribbons with medals, and the patches are out of alignment. In
the military they call a soldier who wears a uniform like that a "rag bag." I guarantee you, any experienced commando would not look like the main character in this movie, and today people are demanding authenticity! Overall, a good movie though. Cordially, Denis C. Berte' (SFC) Special Forces (Ret)
Superlative!

Hard to believe but I actually watched this movie twice within a week. While perhaps the reason for sending Ray to prison was less than convincing the plot within the prison walls was captivating with very decent acting. Very impressed with Officer William's role. Also the camera shots were excellent. Nothing for kids but a gripping movie worth watching multiple times.
So a guy pulls out his junk in public and than pulls a knife and trys to kill you, You defend yourself and others, bad guys dies and you go to jail, WTF,  Good movie anyway.

Unbelievable! People or monkeys shall I say actually behave this way! No humanity, out of fear for survival overcome by bribery and manipulation! Power trips over another human being, despicable self-loathing bullies! Awesome, jaw dropping flick, where bravery and truth overcome. If we all stood up and struck back for what is right like that mofo did, this world may once again stand for something of substance.

It was oookaaay. It wasn't as bad as the 1 star reviews have made it out to be but it was far from as good as the 5 stars made it out to be. I see a lot of bashing on the acting but I don't think the acting was the problem (although the 18 year old kid is the worst actor of all time), it was the overall production. The story dragged on and on. It seemed to me that this could have been a better movie with a re-write and maybe a different director, upped the budget and might as well get a leading star and change about 30 minutes of the film into more action. I will admit I am impressed that this is the first prison movie I have seen without an insane amount of male nudity.

Energetic and committed performances by all the actors. Obviously a labor of love for the lead George Basha, playing Ray Stevens, who also wrote the script and co-directed the movie. Asks questions about racism, economic and power inequality, social responsibility. An enjoyable, if unlikely, ending where justice is served and the powerful are held accountable for their actions.

wow, an Aussie version of Vendetta staring Dean Cain and the Big Show.  This version even had their own look alike of "The Big Show" (Paul Wight), except this Aussie dude was just real tall, thin and ugly as sin.  He finally gets it in the worst place a guy can get it.  Now in Vendetta,  The Big Show with his massive tree trunk upper arms and his towering 7 foot plus giant body rules no matter what he does, whether its in the ring on on screen.  I hope to see more of Paul Wight with more starring roles as hes a natural.  Paul Wight even has huge horse teeth, as nothing is small on this guy.  Vendetta was excellent and maybe a copy of Convict (?)  but was just as good.  Both movies are worth watching more than once.  You can still catch Vendetta on Prime if you haven't already seen it.  This is the second time I've seen Convict.  After seeing Vendetta, I had to re-watch this one.

Ray, a recently released Iraq/Afghanistan veteran gets into an altercation defending his brand new fiancee on the first day he is it of the Army.  The altercation turns violent and a rich man's son dies as a result.  He is sentenced to a few years in prison in a plea bargain.

The Warden is on the take from the dead man's father to make Ray's life miserable.  In typical fashion of several other movies, two mid-level and one low level jailers are perversely happy to do just that.  Things get out if hand eventually and the low level guard wants out.  He gets out all right, but not in the way he might have wanted.

There are a lot of similarites between Ray and most of Jason Statham's characters.  Grin and bearing it are never on the table.  The acting is okay, the action fairly good.  It's definitely better to watch than I had expected.

Take every cliche prison movie you can think of and put them in a blender with a predictable script and borderline acting and you just wasted 1 hour and 42 minutes of your life. This is no Shawshank, and even against other prison movies this one feels like your serving time waiting for the ending or at least early parole. It starts like Con Air, and then follows the same pattern as Felon and many other prison movies but does it with less originality and worse acting.

Anyone who has ever had a boot to your throat by some power tripping goons can relate to this movie.  That feeling where people keep pushing you to the brink, when you have not done anything to deserve it.. That is what this film is like..

Having just watched the British "Starred Up," an astonishingly gritty, realistic British prison drama that feels more like a documentary than fiction, "Convict" comes up woefully short by comparison.  It's not terrible by any means, but it is more than a tad contrived.  Do yourself a favor and watch "Starred Up" instead, you won't be sorry.

He is indited for murder on a clear case of self-defense, but he insisted to go to prison on principle.  The film portrays him as this brave and honest role model.  In the end, he proves he is a criminal when he accepts something that required the killing of innocent people--the film makers and author seem oblivious to this discrepancy.  The film was confused  about what the dirty warden and guards were trying to achieve.  It appeared at one point they were interested in keeping him in prison for life, but they did have the brains to frame him for drugs or murder.  Not realistic.

I could very well give this a four star rating because of how I personally enjoyed the movie, but it not suitable for everyone because of the realistic violence and language it contains. It gives a very graphic depiction of how life is behind bars in a prison. Perhaps if more young people were exposed to this it might redirect them away from the behaviors that could place them in this situation. It seems to be an Australian production because of the accents spoken throughout the movie and that was my one complaint. It was difficult to understand a lot of the dialog because of the speech patterns...again, good but graphic movie...
